FRIDAY, AUGUST 22, 1884.

THE GREELY EXPEDITION

The first, main, and essential characteristic of civilization properly so-called is the increased value given by its methods and its results to the discovery made. The result of this observation of the nature of long seen prevailing customs of settling local disputes or feuds (e.g., those existing between the Highlanders and Lowlanders) has been that they do not appear to the latter as the only possible solution of the question. We cannot imagine that we can persuade the cause may be referred to that great mystery—the introduction of evil into the world for the same purpose, whereupon we should see, at the end of all the labors of human life, should provide such a highly increased tendency to destruction, some of the more convenient means being the implements of murder, which would constitute the part of evident genius in land and water. These reflections are not immediately suggested by a perusal of the humeral account of Mr. Greely's expedition, but the fact of its existence, and its apparent commercial benefit to humanity, must not only by deeply displayed, but also universally condemned by the world as a whole. There could be no doubt, however, that such a publication for such an expedition as has been sent by our government to explore the navigability of Hudson Bay and Strait, even were their aims not approached, produces loss of valuable time which is not the case, because upon the result of that depend the interests of the future, an enormous proportion of the human race, and it is desirable that every precaution be taken to save this great country from ever life to such a cause, but speaking under correction we do not believe that practical results will be found to justify the terrible sacrifices made in the attempt to discover the secrets of the Arctic region. We freely admit ignorance of science despatches the bulk of the general public from forming any exact judgment upon the relative importance of the subject in question; but if the advantages are such as will affect any appreciable proportion of humanity, then they can be explained, directed, or studied to advantage, sufficient clearly to understand into what manner they are obtained. We can all admire and sympathize with the spirit which prompted these efforts, until they had been already proved to the hopelessness of attainment, but until the results are shown to comprise something far beyond material for a few scientific essays on meteorological or similar subjects, we must heartily turn to the consideration of any experiment, which not only gain such vast sums of money, but worse still result in the horrible sufferings only ended by death of so many brave men as have perished in them. Had Lieutenant Greely brought home his men in safety, we can well believe the Americans could pass with patriotic feelings over the loss of some sixty geographic miles nearer the north pole than has been done by any other nation, but when they consider the sickness, details of what prisoners and deaths of their friends and fellow-countrymen involved in all the toils, difficulties, and hardships, full of determined courage to do or die, and then remember how few of themselves will take the trouble to read the reports, to consider the scientific results, the nation large will feel that the game has not been worth the candle, and sometime will have to chance before the past is sufficiently forgotten to encourage further waste of life in the same direction.

ABOUT THE TIMES.

Written for "The Times."

What was once written in Prince Albert newspaper is still there. The article itself is a tale of adventure, filled with suspense and excitement. It describes a journey through the wilderness, where the reader is taken on a thrilling ride through the untamed lands. The author captures the essence of the times, painting a vivid picture of the challenges faced by those who ventured into the unknown. This article is a testament to the spirit of exploration and discovery that permeated society during this era.

PUBLIC NOTICE.

All persons are hereby required to take notice that the entire of lands on the west side of the town without authority from the Ministry of Public Works, are held by the agent of Dominion Land Surveyor for the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, who have been engaged in surveying the same, and who, in consequence thereof, have been instructed by the Minister of the Interior to proceed thereto.

Any person who shall make, or cause to be made, any survey, subdivision or division of any part of the said land without authority from the Minister of Public Works, and who shall, after such survey, subdivision or division, make application therefor to the Dominion Land Surveyor, shall be deemed guilty of an offence punishable by fine or imprisonment, and in the event of conviction thereof, the offender shall be liable to pay a fine of $200.

D. J. WAGNER,

Manager, Timber Agent.

NORTH WEST COUNCIL.

Missouri, July 21, 1884.
The Council met at 2 p.m. His Honor Leslie Murray presiding.

The Hon. read a letter from the Secretary of Justice in reference to an amendment made by Mr. Scovell under Sec. B. of a Bill, stating that the matter would be considered at the next meeting of the Council.

The Solicitor General presented a report on "Ordinance respecting Masters and Servants," with one exception, to-wit: an Amendment to Sec. 2 be amended and his objection raised in favor of Masters.

Mr. Rubel said he was sorry to hear from Mr. Oliver's opinion, and asked for opinions adverse to be received in favor of Masters unless he could get the required two members.

Report agreed to.

RESOLUTIONS INTRODUCED

Judge Hindson—An Ordinance to increase compensation for Masters and servants.

Judge McLuhan—An Ordinance for the Land Commissioner—No. 10 of 1872 for Judge McLuhan—The Municipal Licensing.

Mr. Macdowall moved the following resolution:

That the Council regret the ex- tenuations attributed to Mr. Burgess in a interview with a Gentleman, June 30th, 1879.

2. In the absence of the Governor this Council desires to extend his Excellency the right of iviting on his case by Halberds of these Territories for matters in the nature of land grants.

3. That the interests of the claimants submitted to the Executive Committee to be dealt with.

In moving this resolution, Mr. Olivers said he was aware Mr. Oliver intended introducing a similar resolution in the Legislative Assembly, but he had been instructed by Prince Albert; therefore, he had no right to introduce it.

Mr. Holmes objected, but the proposal was carried by a large majority.

Mr. Oliver moved that the Ordinance be referred to the Executive Committee for consideration.

Mr. Holmes objected but the proposal was carried for consideration.

Mr. Holmes objected but the proposal was carried.

Mr. White moved a resolution: "That it be referred to the Executive Committee to consider the propriety of making such grants towards establishing law courts in each of the several Judicial Districts."

Mr. Tarrill moved the following resolution: "That the present recommendation of the Executive Committee be approved, and that Council recommend that additions be added to private offices for the Clerks of the North West Com- mittee, Commissioner and Library. He then moved unanimously.

Cal. Richardson introduced "Ordinance respecting the Administration of Justice." Resolution considered.

Council resolved itself into committee to consider "Ordinance relating to duties of Justices of the Peace." Ordinance reported.

Mr. Godden introduced "Ordinance respecting stolen horses."

The following Ordinances were consid- ered generally in committee and agreed to:

An Ordinance exempting certain pro- perty from sale and seizure, etc.

An Ordinance prohibiting the destruc- tion of works.

Council adjourned until p.m.

AFTER NOON.

Council resolved itself into committee to consider "The Police Ordinance." Committee rose and reported progress.

Mr. Jackson moved "That the several members of the Council be requested to appoint Committees to examine the provisions of "The Ordinance for the Pro- tection of Game." Resolution con- sidered.

Wednesday, July 29.

The Council met at 2 p.m., His Honor presiding.

The minutes having been read and approved.

A motion was made

Mr. Jackson rose to a question of privi- lege. He referred to an article in the "Prairie Post" of July 16th, where it was stated that a resolution favorable to the establishment of branch lines was passed by the Council. He said he had stated that there was no such resolu- tion, as no such resolution had been passed, though he was aware the same had been mentioned in connection with branch lines.

The Civil Service Committee reported that the ordinance relating to holding land by Trustees for Religious bodies is approved. Report adopted.

Mr. Jackson moved the following reso- lution:

"That the Council do resolve itself into Committee of the Whole to consider and report upon the provisions of "The Ordinance for the Protection of Game." Resolution con- sidered.

The House accordingly resolved itself into committee.

IN COMMITTEE.

Mr. Jackson moved "That $500 be appropriated to the MacLeod District; That $1,000 be appropriated to the Edmonton District; That $1,000 be appropriated to the Calgary District; That $1,000 be appropriated to the Athabasca District; That $500 be appropriated to the Battleford District; That $1,000 be appropriated to the Regina District; That $1,000 be appropriated to the Moose Jaw District; That $1,000 be appropriated to the Qu'Appelle District."

Resolution considered.

Council resolved, Committee reported.

Council again went into committee, considered the ordinance to amend No. 1 of 1879, and "Ordinance respecting Me- chanics Licenses."

Council resolved, Ordinance reported.

The Hon. Governor: "An Ordinance to amend No. 1 of 1883, respecting in- fection diseases among animals."

Tuesday, July 31.

The Council met at 2 p.m., His Honor presiding.

The minutes having been read.

Mr. Godden moved "that it be the opinion of this Council that the interests of the country known as the ranching country, being large and extensive, and situated close together, constitute a natural basis for the organization of stockmen into stock men, should be thrown open for homestead and preemption in all cases where the same has not been claimed under the laws of the Dominion, and that all actual settlers upon land included within the limits of the district, who have been engaged in the terms of the laws, be confirmed in their holdings, both as to homestead and pre- emption."

Resolution considered.

Council went into committee on the school ordinance.

Council resolved, Committee reported.

Council again went into committee on "Ordinance respecting infectious diseases among animals."

Council resolved, Committee reported.

Council again went into committee on "Civil Justice Ordinance."

Council resolved, Committee reported.
